utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Good morning, Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh-huh.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, we’re going to have to stop by Pottery Barn on the way to work, I bought these Star Wars sheets but they turned out to be much too stimulating to be compatible with a good night’s sleep. I don’t like the way Darth Vader stares at me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m not going to work.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, just because your career’s been stagnant for a few years, that’s no reason to give up.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, I was up all night using the new free-electron laser for my X-ray diffraction experiment.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Did the laser accidentally burn out your retinas?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Then you can drive. Let’s go.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Didn’t I tell you I’d be working nights, and that you’d have to make other arrangements.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You did.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: And?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I didn’t. Let’s go.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Goodnight, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: But how am I going to get to work?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Take the bus.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I can’t take the bus any more. They don’t have seatbelts. And they won’t let you lash yourself to the seat with bungee cords.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You tried to lash yourself to the seat with bungee cords?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I didn’t try, I succeeded. For some reason it alarmed the other passengers and I was asked to de-bus.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, you’re a big boy, you’ll figure it out.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Don’t talk to me like I’m a child. Now, take me to return my star wars sheets!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Penny, Penny, Penny…

utterance.speaker: Penny (opening door)
utterance.content: Sheldon, what is it?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard’s asleep.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Thanks for the update

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, wait. You have to drive me to work.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, uh, I really don’t think I do.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: But I don’t drive, and I can’t take the bus.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, honey, you’ll be fine as long as you don’t do that bungee cord thing, okay?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Penny. Didn’t you recently state that you and I are friends?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yes, Sheldon, we are friends.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Then I hereby invoke what I’m given to understand is an integral part of the implied covenant of friendship. The favour.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, dear God.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry, I didn’t realize I was interrupting your morning prayers. When you’re done, we’ll go.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thank you for driving me to work.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You know this is my day off, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, good. I’m not keeping you from anything. Your check engine light is on.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Mm-hmm.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Typically that’s an indicator. To, you know, check your engine.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: It’s fine, it’s been on for, like, a month.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, actually, that would be all the more reason to, you know, check your engine.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, it’s fine.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: If it were fine, the light wouldn’t be on. That’s why the manufacturer installed that light, to let you know it’s not fine.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Uh, maybe the light’s broken.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Is there a “check the check engine light light”? O-o-o-oh!

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Studies have shown that performing tasks such as eating, talking on a cell phone or drinking coffee while driving reduces one’s reaction time by the same factor as an ounce of alcohol.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Do you have any alcohol?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Of course not.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Too bad.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re going up Euclid Avenue?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Mm-hmm.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard takes Los Robles Avenue.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, good for Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Euclid Avenue is shorter as the crow flies, but it has speed bumps, which appreciably increase point-to-point drive time, making it the less efficient choice. But you have the conn. Of course, if you’re not going to slow down for the speed bumps, I withdraw my previous objection. Here’s a fun question. Do you know what the most common street name is?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The answer’s tricky. It’s Second Street. You see, you’d think it would be First Street, but in most towns, First Street eventually gets renamed to something else, you know, like Main Street, Broad Street, Michigan Avenue. Leonard and I often use our commute time to exercise our minds with brain-teasers like that. We also play games. Would you like to play one?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, come on, it’s fun. Ooh! Another bump. Okay. I’ll say an element, and uh, you say an element whose name starts with the last letter of the one I said, okay? I’ll start. Helium. Now, you could say Mercury. That would give me a Y. Ooh. Very clever, that’s a tough one. So I go Ytterbium, which gets you back to M. So you go Molybdenum, and I say Magnesium, you say Manganese, and I say Europium, and, and you’re left with Mendelevium, and there are no more M’s because I believe that Meitnerium should still be called Ekairidium, so congratulations, you win. Do you wanna go again?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: How about we just have a little quiet time now?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right. Hmm, huh, I’m sorry, I’m finding your reckless nonchalance regarding the check-engine light to be very troubling.

utterance.speaker: Penny (Pulling over)
utterance.content: Get out.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, I have to tell you that while I do have a theoretical understanding of the workings of an internal combustion engine, I’m not sure I’m capable of performing diagnostics.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I said, get out.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay. I’ll give it a shot.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, Leonard, there you are, I’m ready to go home.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I just got here.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Good, perfect timing.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, I told you, I only have access to the free-electron laser at night. I can’t drive you for the next few weeks.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, you said you couldn’t drive me to work, this is from work.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Howard, help me out here.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, just for the fun of it, I’m gonna take his side.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Now, how do you propose I get home?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: How did you get here in the first place?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Penny. But I sense that’s no longer an option.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Look, I need to get to the laser lab, you’re just going to have to find someone else to take you home.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh damn, I picked the wrong side.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa! Oh God, not Euclid Avenue! Aaaaaaaaaaaaaa!

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Why did Howard leave you in the middle of the road anyway?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: We had a difference of opinion.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Over what?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Whether or not he was trying to kill me. For the record, I maintain he was. Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m taking you home.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, but I’m not going home. It’s Wednesday, Wednesday is new comic book day, we have to go to the comic book store. And then we have to stop at Soup Plantation, it’s creamy tomato soup day, and Radio Shack, there’s a sale on triple-a batteries. Plus, we have to go to Pottery Barn and return my Star Wars sheets.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I have a better idea.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You want to go to pottery barn first?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Can you drive me to Pottery Barn? Maybe if I turn off the night-light, I can keep the sheets.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Good morning.

utterance.speaker: All
utterance.content: Good morning.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, sit down.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: She’s in my spot. Don’t look at me like that, everybody knows that my spot.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, you know that we care about you.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: And it’s because we care about you that we’ve decided we have to speak up.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You’re hurting the people around you, sweetie.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So we made you an appointment, and we want you to keep it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Department of motor vehicles new driver handbook? But I don’t have a problem.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, you need to learn how to drive.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: This madness has to stop.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Penny’s taking you to the DMV, I’m going to bed.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why Penny?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Because rock breaks scissors, goodnight.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: All right, come on Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hold on, I have one condition.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: We have to stop at Pottery Barn.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: And Radio Shack.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Fine.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: And the comic book store.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: All right!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Ooh, I want to go to the comic book store.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I like comic books.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I just don’t see why I need a driver’s license, Albert Einstein never had a driver’s license.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, but Albert Einstein didn’t make me wet myself at 40 miles an hour.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, and I never wanted to kick Albert Einstein in the nuts. You know, I gotta ask, why didn’t you just get a license at 16 like everybody else?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I was otherwise engaged.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Doing what?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Examining perturbative amplitudes in n=4 supersymmetric theories leading to a re-examination of the ultraviolet properties of multi-loop n=8 supergravity using modern twistor theory.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, how ’bout when you were 17?

utterance.speaker: DMV Lady (to the person ahead of Sheldon in the queue)
utterance.content: Take this to the testing area, put your name at the top, sign the bottom, answer the questions, bring it back, next! Application?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m actually more of a theorist.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: The application in your hand, give it to her.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: DMV Lady
utterance.content: Take this to the testing area, put your name at the top, sign the bottom, answer the questions, bring it back, next!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Excuse me, but I have some concerns about these questions.

utterance.speaker: DMV Lady
utterance.content: Look at that sign up there.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes?

utterance.speaker: DMV Lady
utterance.content: Does it say I give a damn?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: DMV Lady
utterance.content: That’s because I don’t.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Just, look, see, this first question makes no sense, how many car lengths should you leave in front of you when driving? There’s no possible way to answer that, a car length is not a standardized unit of measure.

utterance.speaker: DMV Lady
utterance.content: Look at the sign.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, it’s C, just put down C.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t need your help, Penny.

utterance.speaker: DMV Lady
utterance.content: Listen to that little girl, honey, put C. Next!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, no, wait, no, hang on, look at this next question.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sheldon, why are you arguing with the DMV?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: How else are they going to learn? Look, question 2, when are roadways most slippery? Now, okay, there are three answers, none of which are correct. The correct answer is, when covered by a film of liquid sufficient to reduce the coefficient of static friction between the tire and the road to essentially zero, but not so deep as to introduce a new source of friction.

utterance.speaker: DMV Lady
utterance.content: Here’s your learner’s permit. Go away.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: But I’m not done. I have many additional concerns about these questions.

utterance.speaker: DMV Lady
utterance.content: Don’t make me climb over this counter.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Come on, let’s go.

utterance.speaker: DMV Lady
utterance.content: Next!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Aced it.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, that’s it, let’s boot it up.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Booting.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: This is a state-of-the-art simulator. I adapted it from something a friend of mine designed for the army.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Is that why I appear to be in downtown Fallujah, behind the wheel of an up-armored Humvee?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I haven’t configured it yet. Let’s see… Bradley tank… transport truck… Batmobile…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Ooh!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Here we go, red 2006 Ford Taurus on the streets of Pasadena.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (sucking in breath)
utterance.content: Hmmmm?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Statistically, red cars are stopped by police far more often than any other colour. I don’t want any hassles with the fuzz.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Fine, what colour do you want?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You know the pale blue of Luke Skywalker’s lightsaber, before it was digitally remastered?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Black it is.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, now, what you want to do first is turn on the ignition and shift into drive.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I haven’t fastened my seat belt yet.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, fasten your seat belt.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Click. Now, are there air bags?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You don’t need air bags.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What if a simulated van rear-ends me?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’ll hit you in the face with a pillow.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, now shift into drive, pull out slowly into traffic.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Watch out.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh God!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Watch, watch out, watch out for pedestrians!

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh God, wait, slow, hit the brakes, hit the brakes!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Sorry… excuse me… my bad… student driver…

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: How did you manage to get on the second floor of the Glendale galleria?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t know. I was on the Pasadena freeway, I missed my exit, flew off the overpass, and one thing led to another.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Maybe you want to give it a rest and try again tomorrow.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No. I quit.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Aw, the pet store?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Remind me to compliment Wolowitz on the software, it’s amazingly detailed.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So wait,you’re just gonna give up?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, I’m not giving up, I never give up.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So what is it you’re doing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m transcending the situation. I’m clearly too evolved for driving.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What does that mean?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard, have you ever wondered why my little toes and lateral incisors are significantly smaller than the average for someone of my size?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I wonder a lot of things about you, Sheldon, but not… not that.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, those are indicators that I’m farther along the evolutionary scale than the average human.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No kidding.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, no, no, I’m not going to go so far as to say that I represent a distinct new stage in humankind, you know, a Homo Novus, if you will, no, that’s for anthropologists to decide. But I am convinced that the reason I cannot master the plebeian task of driving is because I’m not meant to.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes, you are, you’re meant to learn how to drive. Please learn how to drive!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, no. Leonard, I’m meant for greater things, like unraveling the mysteries of the universe, not determining when it’s safe to pass a stopped school bus on a country road.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It’s never safe.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, well, I know that now.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Fine. Assuming that everything you say is true, how does the biologically superior Homo Novus get to work tomorrow morning?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Homo Novus doesn’t know.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, hang in there, maybe you’ll evolve into something with wings.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Good morning, gentlemen.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Good morning. Is there some new kind of casual Friday I don’t know about?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, he lives here now.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Really? Why?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, since he won’t take the bus and he’s too evolved to drive, he decided it would be easier to just sleep in his office and shower in the radiation lab until I’m finished with my experiment.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: But you finished your experiment a week ago.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yep

utterance.speaker: Cleaning Lady 1 (in Spanish, subtitles)
utterance.content: Oh my God, again?

utterance.speaker: Cleaning Lady 2
utterance.content: It must be rats.

utterance.speaker: Cleaning Lady 1
utterance.content: Rats don’t make toast and cut off the crust.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You saw nothing!
